"Kinetic coupling"

The standard Gibbs energy of the gas-phase reaction

$\mathrm{Br}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \underset{k_{-5}}{\stackrel{k_{5}}{\rightleftarrows}} \mathrm{HBr}+\mathrm{H}$

is positive, $\Delta G^{\circ}(5)=66 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $T=600 \mathrm{~K}$.

problem:
What is the ratio of the rates of forward and reverse reactions, $r_{5} / r_{-5}$, at this temperature, standard pressures of $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{HBr}$ and equal pressures of $\mathrm{H}$ and $\mathrm{Br}$ ? (If you could not answer this question, for further calculations use reference value $r_{5} / r_{-5}=3.14 \times 10^{-7}$.)

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value.
solution:
The standard Gibbs energy of reaction (5) at $600 \mathrm{~K}^{2}$ is $66 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. The equilibrium constant is

$K=\mathrm{e}^{-66000 / 8.314 / 600}=1.8 \times 10^{-6}=\mathrm{k}_{5} / \mathrm{k}_{-5}$

Reaction is considered at standard pressures of all the reactants and products. The ratio of the rates of forward and reverse reactions is

$\frac{r_{5}}{r_{-5}}=\frac{k_{5}[\mathrm{Br}]\left[\mathrm{H}_{2}\right]}{k_{-5}[\mathrm{HBr}][\mathrm{H}]}=\frac{k_{5}}{k_{-5}}=1.8 \times 10^{-6}$

problem:
IONIC SOLUTIONS - AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS OF COPPER SALTS

This part is about the acidity of the hydrated $\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$ ion and the precipitation of the hydroxide.

Consider a $1.00 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ solution of copper(II) nitrate. The $\mathrm{pH}$ of this solution is 4.65.

Disproportionation of copper(I) ions

The $\mathrm{Cu}^{+}$ion is involved in two redox couples:

Couple 1: $\quad \mathrm{Cu}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu}$

Standard electrode potential $E_{1}^{0}=+0.52 \mathrm{~V}$

Couple 2: $\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu}^{+}$

Standard electrode potential $E_{2}^{0}=+0.16 \mathrm{~V}$

Write down the equation for the disproportionation of copper(I) ions and calculate the corresponding equilibrium constant.

IONIC SOLUTIONS - AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS OF COPPER SALTS

This part is about the acidity of the hydrated $\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$ ion and the precipitation of the hydroxide.

Consider a $1.00 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ solution of copper(II) nitrate. The $\mathrm{pH}$ of this solution is 4.65.

Disproportionation of copper(I) ions

The $\mathrm{Cu}^{+}$ion is involved in two redox couples:

Couple 1: $\quad \mathrm{Cu}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu}$

Standard electrode potential $E_{1}^{0}=+0.52 \mathrm{~V}$

Couple 2: $\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu}^{+}$

Standard electrode potential $E_{2}^{0}=+0.16 \mathrm{~V}$

Write down the equation for the disproportionation of copper(I) ions and calculate the corresponding equilibrium constant.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!

solution:
$2 \mathrm{Cu}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}+\mathrm{Cu}$

$K=\frac{\left[\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{Cu}^{+}\right]^{2}}$

$0.52-0.16=0.059 \log K($ Nernst equation $) \Rightarrow K=1 \times 10^{6}$

problem:
The amount of many reducing agents can be determined by permanganatometric titration in alkaline medium allowing permanganate ion reduction to manganate.A volume of $10.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\left(V_{\mathrm{Mn}}\right)$ of $\mathrm{KMnO}_{4}$ solution with a concentration of 0.0400 mol $\mathrm{dm}^{-3}\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}}\right)$ was placed in each of flasks $\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}$, and $\mathbf{C}$ and different reactions were conducted in each flask.

A sample solution containing crotonic acid (CA) $\mathrm{CH}_{3}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{COOH}$, an alkali and barium nitrate (both in an excess) were added to flask $\mathbf{A}$, and the reaction mixture was incubated for $45 \mathrm{~min}$. It is known that crotonic acid loses 10 electrons under the experiment conditions.

A volume of $8.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\left(V_{\mathrm{CN}}\right)$ of potassium cyanide solution $\left(C_{\mathrm{CN}}=0.0100 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)$ was then added to the incubated mixture. This resulted in completion of the following reaction:

$$
2 \mathrm{Ba}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+\mathrm{CN}^{-}+2 \mathrm{OH}^{-} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{BaMnO}_{4}+\mathrm{CNO}^{-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}
$$

$\mathrm{BaMnO}_{4}$ precipitate was then filtered off, and the excess of cyanide in the filtrate was titrated with $\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ solution $\left(c_{\mathrm{Ag}}=0.0050 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}{ }^{-3}\right.$ ) till detectable precipitation was observed. Note that both $\mathrm{CN}^{-}$and $\mathrm{CNO}^{-}$are analogs of halide ions, but $\mathrm{CNO}^{-}$affords soluble silver salt.

Calculate the mass of crotonic acid (in $\mathrm{mg})$ if $5.40 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\left(V_{\mathrm{Ag}}\right)$ of the silver salt solution was consumed for the titration to the endpoint.

problem:
A volume of $10.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\left(V_{\mathrm{Mn}}\right)$ of $\mathrm{KMnO}_{4}$ solution with a concentration of 0.0400 mol $\mathrm{dm}^{-3}\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}}\right)$ was placed in each of flasks $\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}$, and $\mathbf{C}$ and different reactions were conducted in each flask.

A sample solution containing crotonic acid (CA) $\mathrm{CH}_{3}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{COOH}$, an alkali and barium nitrate (both in an excess) were added to flask $\mathbf{A}$, and the reaction mixture was incubated for $45 \mathrm{~min}$. It is known that crotonic acid loses 10 electrons under the experiment conditions.

A volume of $8.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\left(V_{\mathrm{CN}}\right)$ of potassium cyanide solution $\left(C_{\mathrm{CN}}=0.0100 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)$ was then added to the incubated mixture. This resulted in completion of the following reaction:

$$
2 \mathrm{Ba}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+\mathrm{CN}^{-}+2 \mathrm{OH}^{-} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{BaMnO}_{4}+\mathrm{CNO}^{-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}
$$

$\mathrm{BaMnO}_{4}$ precipitate was then filtered off, and the excess of cyanide in the filtrate was titrated with $\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ solution $\left(c_{\mathrm{Ag}}=0.0050 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}{ }^{-3}\right.$ ) till detectable precipitation was observed. Note that both $\mathrm{CN}^{-}$and $\mathrm{CNO}^{-}$are analogs of halide ions, but $\mathrm{CNO}^{-}$affords soluble silver salt.

Calculate the mass of crotonic acid (in $\mathrm{mg})$ if $5.40 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\left(V_{\mathrm{Ag}}\right)$ of the silver salt solution was consumed for the titration to the endpoint.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of mg, but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.
solution:
Permanganate left after the reaction with crotonic acid: $c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-10 n_{\mathrm{CA}}$ (mmol).

Cyanide consumed for the residual permanganate: $1 / 2\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-10 n_{\mathrm{CA}}\right)$ (mmol).

Cyanide excess: $c_{\mathrm{CN}} V_{\mathrm{CN}}-1 / 2\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-10 n_{\mathrm{CA}}\right)$

For the correct silver-cyanide stoichiometry $(1: 2)$ :

$2 c_{\mathrm{Ag}} V_{\mathrm{Ag}}=c_{\mathrm{CN}} V_{\mathrm{CN}}-1 / 2\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-10 n_{\mathrm{CA}}\right)$.

Thus: $n_{\mathrm{CA}}=\frac{2 c_{\mathrm{Ag}} V_{\mathrm{Ag}}-c_{\mathrm{CN}} V_{\mathrm{CN}}+1 / 2 c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}}{5}$

$n_{\mathrm{CA}}=\frac{2 \times 0.005 \times 5.40-0.0100 \times 8.00+0.5 \times 0.0400 \times 10.00}{5}=0.0348 \mathrm{mmol}$,

Then:

$m_{\mathrm{CA}}=0.0348 \times 86.09=3.00 \mathrm{mg} \quad\left(M_{\mathrm{CA}}=86.09 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\right)$.

For the wrong silver-cyanide stoichiometry $(1: 1)$ :

$c_{\mathrm{Ag}} V_{\mathrm{Ag}}=c_{\mathrm{CN}} V_{\mathrm{CN}}-1 / 2\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-10 n_{\mathrm{CA}}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n_{\mathrm{CA}}=\frac{c_{\mathrm{Ag}} V_{\mathrm{Ag}}-c_{\mathrm{CN}} V_{\mathrm{CN}}+1 / 2 c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}}{5} \\
& n_{\mathrm{CA}}=\frac{0.005 \times 5.40-0.0100 \times 8.00+0.5 \times 0.0400 \times 10.00}{5}=0.0290 \mathrm{mmol}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$m_{\mathrm{CA}}=0.0290 \times 86.09=2.49 \mathrm{mg}$

problem:
Anhydrous ammonia is an ultra-clean, energy-dense alternative liquid fuel. It produces no greenhouse gases on combustion.

In an experiment, gaseous $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ is burned with $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ in a container of fixed volume according to the equation given below.

$$
4 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(g)+3 \mathrm{O}_{2}(g) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{~N}_{2}(g)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l)
$$

The initial and final states are at $298 \mathrm{~K}$. After combustion with $14.40 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$, some of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ remains unreacted.Calculate the heat released during the process.
$$
\Delta_{f} H^{0}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}(g)\right)=-46.11 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \text { and } \Delta_{f} H^{0}\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l)\right)=-285.83 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}
$$
prompt:
You are participating in an international Chemistry competition and need to solve the following question.
The answer to this question is a numerical value.
Here is some context information for this question, which might assist you in solving it:
Anhydrous ammonia is an ultra-clean, energy-dense alternative liquid fuel. It produces no greenhouse gases on combustion.

In an experiment, gaseous $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ is burned with $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ in a container of fixed volume according to the equation given below.

$$
4 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(g)+3 \mathrm{O}_{2}(g) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{~N}_{2}(g)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l)
$$

The initial and final states are at $298 \mathrm{~K}$. After combustion with $14.40 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$, some of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ remains unreacted.

problem:
Calculate the heat released during the process.
$$
\Delta_{f} H^{0}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}(g)\right)=-46.11 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \text { and } \Delta_{f} H^{0}\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l)\right)=-285.83 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}
$$

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of kJ, but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.
solution:
$q_{\mathrm{v}}=\Delta E=\Delta H-\Delta n_{\mathrm{g}} R T$

For 1 mole of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ :

$\Delta H=3 / 2 \times(-285.83)-(-46.11)=-382.64 \mathrm{~kJ}$

$\Delta n_{\mathrm{g}}=-1.25 \mathrm{~mol}$

$\Delta E=-382.64 \mathrm{~kJ}-\left[(-1.25 \mathrm{~mol}) \times 8.314 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \times 298 \mathrm{~K}\right]=-379.5 \mathrm{~kJ}$

$n\left(\mathrm{O}_{2}\right)=\frac{14.4 \mathrm{~g}}{32.0 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}}=0.450 \mathrm{~mol}$

$n\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{\text {reacted }}=0.450 \mathrm{~mol} \times 4 / 3=0.600 \mathrm{~mol}$

$q_{\mathrm{v}}=\Delta E=0.600 \mathrm{~mol} \times\left(-379.5 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\right)=\underline{-227.7 \mathrm{~kJ}}$

The numbers shown in the table are the atomic masses as known at the time. ## the misplacement of thallium

Mendeleev also misplaced the highly toxic element thallium ( $\mathrm{Tl}$ ) with the elements from Group 1 rather than in Group 13. There are good reasons for this error. Thallium can form salts in the +3 oxidation state like other members of its group, but $\mathrm{Tl}^{3+}$ ions are oxidising and the most stable oxidation state is +1 . Here is some context information for this question, which might assist you in solving it:
Thiomolybdate ions are derived from molybdate ions, $\mathrm{MoO}_{4}^{2-}$, by replacing oxygen atoms with sulfur atoms. In nature, thiomolybdate ions are found in such places as the deep waters of the Black Sea, where biological sulfate reduction generates $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$. The molybdate to thiomolybdate transformation leads to rapid loss of dissolved Mo from seawater to underlying sediments, depleting the ocean in Mo, a trace element essential for life.

The following equilibria control the relative concentrations of molybdate and thiomolybdate ions in dilute aqueous solution:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{1}=1.3 \cdot 10^{-5} \\
\mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{2}=1.0 \cdot 10^{-5} \\
\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{3} \mathrm{~S}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{3}=1.6 \cdot 10^{-5} \\
\mathrm{MoO}_{3} \mathrm{~S}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{4}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{4}=6.5 \cdot 10^{-6}
\end{array}
$$

problem:
If at equilibrium the concentrations of $\mathrm{MoO}_{4}^{2-}$ and $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq})$ are equal to $1 \cdot 10^{-7}$ and $1 \cdot 10^{-6}$, respectively, what would be the equilibrium concentration of $\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}$ ?

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value.
solution:
Multiplying the mass action laws for the four given reactions produces:

$\frac{\left[\mathrm{MoO}_{4}^{2-}\right]\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}\right]^{4}}{\left[\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}\right]}=\frac{1 \cdot 10^{-7}\left(1 \cdot 10^{-6}\right)^{4}}{\left[\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}\right]}=1.4 \cdot 10^{-20}$

$\left[\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}\right]=7 \cdot 10^{-12}$

problem:
This question is about benzene and its isomers

Working out the structure of benzene, $\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{6}$, was one of the great achievements of $19^{\text {th }}$ century chemists. The carcinogenic hydrocarbon was first discovered by Michael Faraday at the Royal Institution in 1825 during the repeated fractional distillation of some oil residues.

Faraday analysed the pure benzene by passing its vapour over heated copper(II) oxide to produce carbon dioxide, water and copper. He collected and measured the volume of liquid water and gaseous $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ produced from a given mass of benzene.

Assuming $1.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of a gas occupies $24.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ at room temperature and pressure, calculate the volume of carbon dioxide that could be produced from $0.644 \mathrm{mmol}$ of benzene. Give your answer in $\mathrm{cm}^{3}$.

problem:
This question is about benzene and its isomers

Working out the structure of benzene, $\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{6}$, was one of the great achievements of $19^{\text {th }}$ century chemists. The carcinogenic hydrocarbon was first discovered by Michael Faraday at the Royal Institution in 1825 during the repeated fractional distillation of some oil residues.

Faraday analysed the pure benzene by passing its vapour over heated copper(II) oxide to produce carbon dioxide, water and copper. He collected and measured the volume of liquid water and gaseous $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ produced from a given mass of benzene.

Assuming $1.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of a gas occupies $24.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ at room temperature and pressure, calculate the volume of carbon dioxide that could be produced from $0.644 \mathrm{mmol}$ of benzene. Give your answer in $\mathrm{cm}^{3}$.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of cm^3, but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.
solution:
Volume produced:

1 mole of benzene will form 6 moles of carbon dioxide.

$0.644 \mathrm{mmol}$ of benzene will form $6 \times 0.644=3.864 \mathrm{mmol}$ carbon dioxide

$$
=0.003864 \mathrm{~mol}
$$

0.003864 moles of carbon dioxide will occupy $0.003864 \times 24 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$

$$
=0.0927 \mathrm{dm}^{3}=92.7 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} 
$$

problem:
Iron $(\mathrm{Fe})$ is the fourth most abundant element in the Earth's crust and has been used for more than 5,000 years.

Pure iron is easily oxidized, which limits its utilization. Element $\mathbf{X}$ is one of the alloying elements that is added to improve the oxidation resistance property of iron.Both $\mathrm{Fe}$ and $\mathrm{X}$ crystallize in the body centered cubic structure. Approximating the Fe atoms as hard-spheres, the volume taken up by the Fe atoms inside the unit cell is $1.59 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$. The volume of the unit cell of $\mathbf{X}$ is $0.0252 \mathrm{~nm}^{3}$. A complete substitutional solid solution usually occurs when

$$
\Delta R=\left(\frac{\left|R_{x}-R_{F e}\right|}{R_{F e}}\right) \times 100
$$

is less than or equal to 15 , where $R_{X}$ and $R_{F e}$ are the atomic radii of $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathrm{Fe}$, respectively. Can $\mathbf{X}$ and Fe form a complete substitutional solid solution?

Show your calculation. The volume of sphere is $4 / 3 \pi r^{3}$.
prompt:
You are participating in an international Chemistry competition and need to solve the following question.
This is a True or False question.
Here is some context information for this question, which might assist you in solving it:
Iron $(\mathrm{Fe})$ is the fourth most abundant element in the Earth's crust and has been used for more than 5,000 years.

Pure iron is easily oxidized, which limits its utilization. Element $\mathbf{X}$ is one of the alloying elements that is added to improve the oxidation resistance property of iron.

problem:
Both $\mathrm{Fe}$ and $\mathrm{X}$ crystallize in the body centered cubic structure. Approximating the Fe atoms as hard-spheres, the volume taken up by the Fe atoms inside the unit cell is $1.59 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$. The volume of the unit cell of $\mathbf{X}$ is $0.0252 \mathrm{~nm}^{3}$. A complete substitutional solid solution usually occurs when

$$
\Delta R=\left(\frac{\left|R_{x}-R_{F e}\right|}{R_{F e}}\right) \times 100
$$

is less than or equal to 15 , where $R_{X}$ and $R_{F e}$ are the atomic radii of $\mathbf{X}$ and $\mathrm{Fe}$, respectively. Can $\mathbf{X}$ and Fe form a complete substitutional solid solution?

Show your calculation. The volume of sphere is $4 / 3 \pi r^{3}$.

You can solve it step by step.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER should be either "True" or "False".
solution:
The correct answer:  YES (since $\Delta \mathrm{R} \leq 15$ )

## Calculation

For Fe:

$V=2(4 / 3) \pi r^{3}$ (the bcc unit cell contains 2 atoms of Fe)

$r^{3}=\left(3 \mathrm{~V} /(8 \pi)=\left(3 \times 1.59 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\right) /(8 \pi)=1.90 \times 10^{-24} \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\right.$

$r=1.24 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~cm}$ i. e. $r=0.124 \mathrm{~nm}$

For $X$ :

[figure1]

$V=a^{3} \Rightarrow a=\sqrt[3]{\nabla}=\sqrt[3]{0.0252}=0.293 \mathrm{~nm}$

$r=(a \sqrt[3]{3}) / 4=(0.293 \mathrm{~nm} \times \sqrt[3]{3}) / 4=0.127 \mathrm{~nm}$

$\Delta R=\left(\frac{\left|R_{X}-R_{F e}\right|}{R_{F e}}\right) \times 100=\left(\frac{|0.127 \mathrm{~nm}-0.124 \mathrm{~nm}|}{0.124 \mathrm{~nm}}\right) \times 100=2.42$

(less than 15)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& R_{F e}=0.124 \mathrm{~nm} \\
& R_{X}=0.127 \mathrm{~nm}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\Delta \mathrm{R}=2.42
$$

problem:
Anhydrous ammonia is an ultra-clean, energy-dense alternative liquid fuel. It produces no greenhouse gases on combustion.

In an experiment, gaseous $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ is burned with $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ in a container of fixed volume according to the equation given below.

$$
4 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(g)+3 \mathrm{O}_{2}(g) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{~N}_{2}(g)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l)

Anhydrous ammonia is an ultra-clean, energy-dense alternative liquid fuel. It produces no greenhouse gases on combustion.

In an experiment, gaseous $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ is burned with $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ in a container of fixed volume according to the equation given below.

$$
4 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(g)+3 \mathrm{O}_{2}(g) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{~N}_{2}(g)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l)
$$

The initial and final states are at $298 \mathrm{~K}$. After combustion with $14.40 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$, some of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ remains unreacted.

To determine the amount of $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ gas dissolved in water, produced during the combustion process, a $10.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ sample of the aqueous solution was withdrawn from the reaction vessel and added to $15.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ solution $\left(c=0.0100 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ). The resulting solution was titrated with a standard $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution $\left(c=0.0200 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ) and the equivalence point was reached at $10.64 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$.

$$
\left(K_{b}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)=1.8 \cdot 10^{-5} ; \quad K_{a}\left(\mathrm{HSO}_{4}^{-}\right)=1.1 \cdot 10^{-2}\right)
$$

problem:
Calculate $\mathrm{pH}$ of the solution in the container after combustion.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!

solution:
Total $n\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\right)=15.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \times 0.0100 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}=0.150 \mathrm{mmol}$

$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}+2 \mathrm{NaOH} \rightarrow \mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$

After back titration with $\mathrm{NaOH}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\right)_{\text {reacted }}=1 / 2 n(\mathrm{NaOH})_{\text {reacted }}=1 / 2\left(0.01064 \mathrm{dm}^{3} \times 0.0200 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)= \\
& =1.064 \cdot 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mol}=0.1064 \mathrm{mmol} \\
& n\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\right) \text { reacted with } \mathrm{NH}_{3}=0.0436 \mathrm{mmol} \\
& 2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \rightarrow\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \\
& n\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)=2 \times n\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\right) \text { reacted with } \mathrm{NH}_{3}=2 \times 0.0436 \mathrm{mmol}=0.0872 \mathrm{mmol} \\
& c\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)=\frac{0.0872 \mathrm{mmol}}{0.0100 \mathrm{dm}^{3}}=8.72 \cdot 10^{-3} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3} \\
& \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(I) \rightleftarrows \mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{OH}^{-}(\mathrm{aq}) \\
& \begin{array}{llll}
c-x & x & x
\end{array} \\
& K_{b}=1.8 \cdot 10^{-5}=\frac{x^{2}}{0.00872-x} \\
& x=[\mathrm{OH}]=3.96 \cdot 10^{-4} \\
& \mathrm{pOH}=3.41 \\
& p H=10.59
\end{aligned}
$$

## the tellurium-iodine problem

Although the elements in Mendeleev's table are primarily arranged by atomic mass, this was not the case with tellurium (Te) and iodine. Mendeleev realised that the chemical properties of the elements meant that tellurium had to come before iodine, but the atomic masses did not support this order. He marked the mass of tellurium with a question mark to highlight its suspicious value.

The modern value for the relative atomic mass of tellurium is one of the least precise: $127.60 \pm$ 0.03 . The reason for the uncertainty is that naturally occurring tellurium is a mix of 8 different isotopes whose proportions can vary depending on the sample. In contrast, naturally occurring iodine consists of a single isotope - iodine 127 - and so its relative mass is known to a high precision: $126.904472 \pm 0.000003$.

How many electrons does an iodide ion contain?

Here is some context information for this question, which might assist you in solving it:
Distribution and mobility of phosphorus in soil are usually studied by sequential extraction. Sequential extraction is performed by the use of acid or alkaline reagents to fractionate inorganic phosphorus in soil. Soil sample was extracted and analyzed as follows:

A $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of aqueous sample of ammonium phosphomolybdate $\left(\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{3} \mathrm{PMo}_{12} \mathrm{O}_{40}\right)$ compound is extracted with $5.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of an organic solvent. The organic-water partition coefficient (Kow) is defined as the ratio of the concentration of the compound in the organic phase $\left(c_{0}\right)$ to that in the water phase $\left(c_{w}\right)$. Kow of the ammonium phosphomolybdate is 5.0 .

The molar absorptivity of ammonium phosphomolybdate in the organic phase is $5000 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ $\mathrm{mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$.

problem:
If the absorbance in the organic phase is 0.200 , calculate the total mass of phosphorus (in $\mathrm{mg}$ unit) in the original aqueous sample solution. The optical pathlength of the cuvette is $1.00 \mathrm{~cm}$.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of mg, but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.
solution:
$C_{0}=0.200 / 5000=4 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$

The volume of the organic phase is $5.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$, therefore ammonium phosphormolybdate in the organic phase:

$=\left(4 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)\left(5 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\right) / 1000 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}=2 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~mol}$

From $\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{ow}}=\mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{o}} / \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{w}}=5.0$

$C_{\mathrm{w}}=\left(4 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right) / 5=8 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$

The volume of the aqueous solution is $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$, therefore ammonium phosphormolybdate in the aqueous solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left(8 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)\left(100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\right) / 1000 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \mathrm{dm}^{-3} \\
& =8 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~mol}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the total amount of substance of ammonium phosphomolybdate $=$ $=\left(2 \times 10^{-7}\right)+\left(8 \times 10^{-7}\right) \mathrm{mol}=1 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol}$

Total mass of $P=\left(1 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol}\right) \times\left(30.97 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\right) \times\left(1000 \mathrm{mg} \mathrm{g}^{-1}\right)=0.031 \mathrm{mg}$

problem:
Thiomolybdate ions are derived from molybdate ions, $\mathrm{MoO}_{4}^{2-}$, by replacing oxygen atoms with sulfur atoms. In nature, thiomolybdate ions are found in such places as the deep waters of the Black Sea, where biological sulfate reduction generates $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$. The molybdate to thiomolybdate transformation leads to rapid loss of dissolved Mo from seawater to underlying sediments, depleting the ocean in Mo, a trace element essential for life. The following equilibria control the relative concentrations of molybdate and thiomolybdate ions in dilute aqueous solution: $$ \begin{array}{ll} \mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{1}=1.3 \cdot 10^{-5} \\ \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{2}=1.0 \cdot 10^{-5} \\ \mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{3} \mathrm{~S}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{3}=1.6 \cdot 10^{-5} \\ \mathrm{MoO}_{3} \mathrm{~S}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{4}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{4}=6.5 \cdot 10^{-6} \end{array} $$ Solutions containing $\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}, \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}$ and $\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}$ display absorption peaks in the visible wavelength range at 395 and $468 \mathrm{~nm}$. The other ions, as well as $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$, absorb negligibly in the visible wavelength range. The molar absorptivities $(\varepsilon)$ at these two wavelengths are given in the following table: | | $\varepsilon$ at $468 \mathrm{~nm}$
$\mathrm{dm}^{3} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$ | $\varepsilon$ at $395 \mathrm{~nm}$
$\mathrm{dm}^{3} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$ | | :---: | :---: | :---: | | $\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}$ | 11870 | 120 | | $\mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}$ | 0 | 9030 | | $\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}$ | 0 | 3230 |A solution not at equilibrium contains a mixture of $\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}, \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}$ and $\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}$ and no other Mo-containing species. The total concentration of all species containing Mo is $6.0 \cdot 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~dm}^{-3}$. In a $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}$ absorption cell, the absorbance of the solution at $468 \mathrm{~nm}$ is 0.365 and that at $395 \mathrm{~nm}$ is 0.213 . Calculate the concentrations of all three Mo-containing anions in this mixture.

The following equilibria control the relative concentrations of molybdate and thiomolybdate ions in dilute aqueous solution: $$ \begin{array}{ll} \mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{1}=1.3 \cdot 10^{-5} \\ \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{2}=1.0 \cdot 10^{-5} \\ \mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{3} \mathrm{~S}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{3}=1.6 \cdot 10^{-5} \\ \mathrm{MoO}_{3} \mathrm{~S}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{l}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MoO}_{4}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}(\mathrm{aq}) & K_{4}=6.5 \cdot 10^{-6} \end{array} $$ Solutions containing $\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}, \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}$ and $\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}$ display absorption peaks in the visible wavelength range at 395 and $468 \mathrm{~nm}$. The other ions, as well as $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}$, absorb negligibly in the visible wavelength range. The molar absorptivities $(\varepsilon)$ at these two wavelengths are given in the following table: | | $\varepsilon$ at $468 \mathrm{~nm}$
$\mathrm{dm}^{3} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$ | $\varepsilon$ at $395 \mathrm{~nm}$
$\mathrm{dm}^{3} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$ | | :---: | :---: | :---: | | $\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}$ | 11870 | 120 | | $\mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}$ | 0 | 9030 | | $\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}$ | 0 | 3230 | problem: A solution not at equilibrium contains a mixture of $\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}, \mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}$ and $\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}$ and no other Mo-containing species. The total concentration of all species containing Mo is $6.0 \cdot 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~dm}^{-3}$. In a $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}$ absorption cell, the absorbance of the solution at $468 \mathrm{~nm}$ is 0.365 and that at $395 \mathrm{~nm}$ is 0.213 . Calculate the concentrations of all three Mo-containing anions in this mixture. All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX! You can solve it step by step. Your final quantities should be output in the following order: [the concentrations of $\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}$, the concentrations of $\mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}$ , the concentrations of $\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}$]. Their units are, in order, [ $\mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~dm}^{-3}$, $\mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~dm}^{-3}$, $\mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~dm}^{-3}$], but units shouldn't be included in your concluded answer. Their answer types are, in order, [numerical value, numerical value, numerical value]. Please end your response with: "The final answers are \boxed{ANSWER}", where ANSWER should be the sequence of your final answers, separated by commas, for example: 5, 7, 2.5
solution:
$\operatorname{MoS}_{4}^{2-}$ concentration is determined by absorbance at $468 \mathrm{~nm}$ :

$0.365=11870 \times 10.0 \times c\left(\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}\right)$

$c\left(\operatorname{MoS}_{4}^{2-}\right)=3.08 \cdot 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$

From conservation of Mo:

$$
\begin{aligned}
c\left(\mathrm{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}\right)+c\left(\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}\right) & =c(\mathrm{Mo})_{\text {Total }}-c\left(\mathrm{MoS}_{4}^{2-}\right)= \\
& =\left(6.0 \cdot 10^{-6}-3.08 \cdot 10^{-6}\right) \mathrm{mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}=2.9 \cdot 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}
\end{aligned}
$$

By rearrangement:

$c\left(\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}\right)=2.9 \cdot 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}-c\left(\operatorname{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}\right)$

From optical absorbance at $395 \mathrm{~nm}$ (quantities in the equations are without dimensions):

$0.213=\left(120 \times 10.0 \times 3.08 \cdot 10^{-6}\right)+\left(9030 \times 10.0 \times c\left(\operatorname{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}\right)\right)+$

$$
+\left(3230 \times 10.0 \times c\left(\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}\right)\right)
$$

$0.213=\left(120 \times 10.0 \times 3.08 \cdot 10^{-6}\right)+\left(9030 \times 10.0 \times c\left(\operatorname{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}\right)\right)+$

$$
+(3230)(10.0)\left(2.9 \cdot 10^{-6}-c\left(\operatorname{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}\right)\right)
$$

$c\left(\operatorname{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}\right)=2.0 \cdot 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$

$c\left(\mathrm{MoO}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2}^{2-}\right)=2.9 \cdot 10^{-6}-c\left(\operatorname{MoOS}_{3}^{2-}\right)=0.9 \cdot 10^{-6} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$

problem:
One of the strongest evidences for the monoatomicity of argon and helium is the ratio of the heat capacity under constant pressure to that at constant volume, $\gamma=C_{p} / C_{V}$, which is exactly $5 / 3(1.67 \pm 0.01)$ for a monoatomic gas. The ratio was derived from the measurement of speed of sound $v_{\mathrm{s}}$ by using the following equation, where $f$ and $\lambda$ are the frequency and wavelength of the sound, and $R, T$, and $M$ denote the molar gas constant, absolute temperature, and molar mass, respectively.

$$
v_{\mathrm{s}}=f \lambda=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma R T}{M}}
$$

For an unknown gas sample, the wavelength of the sound was measured to be $\lambda=0.116 \mathrm{~m}$ at a frequency of $f=3520 \mathrm{~Hz}\left(\mathrm{~Hz}=\mathrm{s}^{-1}\right)$ and temperature of $15.0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and
under atmospheric pressure $\left(1.013 \cdot 10^{5} \mathrm{~Pa}\right)$. The density $\rho$ of the gas for these conditions was measured to be $0.850 \pm 0.005 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$.Calculate the heat capacity ratio $\gamma$ for this gas sample.
prompt:
You are participating in an international Chemistry competition and need to solve the following question.

Here is some context information for this question, which might assist you in solving it:
One of the strongest evidences for the monoatomicity of argon and helium is the ratio of the heat capacity under constant pressure to that at constant volume, $\gamma=C_{p} / C_{V}$, which is exactly $5 / 3(1.67 \pm 0.01)$ for a monoatomic gas. The ratio was derived from the measurement of speed of sound $v_{\mathrm{s}}$ by using the following equation, where $f$ and $\lambda$ are the frequency and wavelength of the sound, and $R, T$, and $M$ denote the molar gas constant, absolute temperature, and molar mass, respectively.

$$
v_{\mathrm{s}}=f \lambda=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma R T}{M}}
$$

For an unknown gas sample, the wavelength of the sound was measured to be $\lambda=0.116 \mathrm{~m}$ at a frequency of $f=3520 \mathrm{~Hz}\left(\mathrm{~Hz}=\mathrm{s}^{-1}\right)$ and temperature of $15.0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and
under atmospheric pressure $\left(1.013 \cdot 10^{5} \mathrm{~Pa}\right)$. The density $\rho$ of the gas for these conditions was measured to be $0.850 \pm 0.005 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$.

problem:
Calculate the heat capacity ratio $\gamma$ for this gas sample.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value.
solution:
From the equation for the sonic velocity, $f \lambda=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma R T}{M}}$,

$\gamma=\frac{M}{R T}(f \lambda)^{2}=\frac{2.01 \cdot 10^{-2}}{8.314 \times 288.15}(3520 \times 0.116)^{2}=1.40$

(or using $\left.\frac{M}{R T}=\frac{\rho}{p}, \quad \gamma=\frac{\rho}{p}(f \lambda)^{2}=\frac{0.850}{1.013 \cdot 10^{5}}(3520 \times 0.116)^{2}=1.40\right)$

##  electron configurations

We now know that elements in the same Group of the periodic table have similar properties because they have the same number of electrons in their outermost (valence) shell. In Mendeleev's second table, elements in the same Group have the same number of valence electrons, even though some elements are from the main block of the periodic table, and some from the transition metals.

Our modern periodic table is based on the electronic configurations of the elements.

For elements from Groups 1 and 2, the valence electrons are in $s$ orbitals whereas for elements in Groups 13-18, they are in $s$ and $p$ orbitals. In both cases the orbitals have principal quantum numbers the same as the period number.

For elements in Groups 3-12, the electrons are filling d orbitals in shells with principal quantum numbers one less that the period number. The valence electrons are the s electrons and perhaps some / all of the d electrons.

For the lanthanoids and actinoids, the electrons are filling $f$ orbitals in shells with principal quantum numbers two less than the period number.

Use the periodic table to write down the full electronic configuration of oganesson $(\mathrm{Og})$, the last element of the periodic table.

problem:
A feathery, greenish solid precipitate can be observed if chlorine gas is bubbled into water close to its freezing point. Similar precipitates form with other gases such as methane and noble gases. These materials are interesting because vast quantities of the so-called methane-hydrates are supposed to exist in nature (comparable in quantity with other natural gas deposits).

These precipitates all have related structures. The molecules of water just above its freezing point form a hydrogen-bonded structure. The gas molecules stabilize this framework by filling in the rather large cavities in the water structure forming clathrates. The crystals of chlorine and methane clathrates have the same structure. Their main characteristics are dodecahedra formed from 20 water molecules. The unit cell of the crystal can be thought as a body-centered cubic arrangement built from these dodecahedra which are almost spherical objects. The dodecahedra are connected via additional water molecules located on the faces of the unit cell. Two water molecules can be found on each face of the unit cell. The unit cell has an edge dimension of $1.182 \mathrm{~nm}$. There are two types of cavities in this structure. One is the internal space in the dodecahedra (A). These are somewhat smaller than the other type of voids (B), of which there are 6 for each unit cell.

Methane hydrate is formed with the structure in c) at temperatures between $0-10{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. What is the density of the clathrate?

problem:
A feathery, greenish solid precipitate can be observed if chlorine gas is bubbled into water close to its freezing point. Similar precipitates form with other gases such as methane and noble gases. These materials are interesting because vast quantities of the so-called methane-hydrates are supposed to exist in nature (comparable in quantity with other natural gas deposits).

The gas molecules stabilize this framework by filling in the rather large cavities in the water structure forming clathrates. The crystals of chlorine and methane clathrates have the same structure. Their main characteristics are dodecahedra formed from 20 water molecules. The unit cell of the crystal can be thought as a body-centered cubic arrangement built from these dodecahedra which are almost spherical objects. The dodecahedra are connected via additional water molecules located on the faces of the unit cell. Two water molecules can be found on each face of the unit cell. The unit cell has an edge dimension of $1.182 \mathrm{~nm}$. There are two types of cavities in this structure. One is the internal space in the dodecahedra (A). These are somewhat smaller than the other type of voids (B), of which there are 6 for each unit cell.

Methane hydrate is formed with the structure in c) at temperatures between $0-10{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. What is the density of the clathrate?

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of $\mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$., but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.
solution:
A unit cell has a volume of $1.182^{3} \mathrm{~nm}^{3}=1.651 \mathrm{~nm}^{3}$.

It contains 8 methane and 46 water molecules with a mass of $957 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} / \mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{A}}=$ $1.589 \times 10^{-21} \mathrm{~g}$.

The density is $1.589 / 1.651=0.962 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$.

problem:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.A buffer solution is added to solution $\mathbf{Y}$ to maintain a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 10.0. Assume no change in volume of the resulting solution $\mathbf{Z}$. Calculate the solubility (in $\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ ) of the substance $\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}$ in $\mathbf{Z}$, taking into consideration that the anions $\mathrm{A}^{-}$and $\mathrm{B}^{-}$can form complexes with $\mathrm{M}^{2+}$ :

$\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2} \leftrightharpoons \mathrm{M}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{OH}^{-} \quad K_{s p}=3.10 \times 10^{-12}$

$\mathrm{M}^{2+}+\mathrm{A}^{-} \leftrightharpoons[\mathrm{MA}]^{+} \quad K_{1}=2.1 \times 10^{3}$

$[\mathrm{MA}]^{+}+\mathrm{A}^{-} \leftrightharpoons\left[\mathrm{MA}_{2}\right] \quad K_{2}=5.0 \times 10^{2}$

$\mathrm{M}^{2+}+\mathrm{B}^{-} \leftrightharpoons[\mathrm{MB}]^{+} \quad \mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}=6.2 \times 10^{3}$

$[\mathrm{MB}]^{+}+\mathrm{B}^{-} \leftrightharpoons\left[\mathrm{MB}_{2}\right] \quad \mathrm{K}_{2}^{\prime}=3.3 \times 10^{2}$

solution:
| $ \mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}$ | $\leftrightharpoons \mathrm{M}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{OH}^{-}$ | $\mathrm{K}_{s p}=3.10 \times 10^{-12}$ |
| ---: | :--- | ---: | :--- |
| $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ | $\leftrightharpoons \mathrm{H}^{+}+\mathrm{OH}^{-}$ | $K_{w}=1.00 \times 10^{-14}$ |
| $\mathrm{M}^{2+}+\mathrm{A}^{-} \leftrightharpoons[\mathrm{MA}]^{+}$ | $\mathrm{K}_{1}=2.10 \times 10^{3}$ |  |
| $[\mathrm{MA}]^{+}+\mathrm{A}^{-} \leftrightharpoons\left[\mathrm{MA}_{2}\right]$ | $K_{2}=5.00 \times 10^{2}$ |  |
| $\mathrm{M}^{2+}+\mathrm{B}^{-}$ | $\leftrightharpoons\left[\mathrm{MB}^{+}\right.$ | $K_{1}^{\prime}=6.20 \times 10^{3}$ |
| $[\mathrm{MB}]^{+}+\mathrm{B}^{-}$ | $\leftrightharpoons\left[\mathrm{MB}_{2}\right]$ | $\mathrm{K}_{2}=3.30 \times 10^{2}$ |

Solubility of $\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}=\mathrm{s}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{2+}\right]+\left[\mathrm{MA}^{+}\right]+\left[\mathrm{MA}_{2}\right]+\left[\mathrm{MB}^{+}\right]+\left[\mathrm{MB}_{2}\right]$

$\mathrm{pH}$ of $\mathbf{Z}=10.0$
$\left[\mathrm{M}^{2+}\right]=\frac{K_{s p}}{\left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right]^{2}}=\frac{3.10 \times 10^{-12}}{\left(1 \times 10^{-4}\right)^{2}}=3.10 \times 10^{-4}$

Eq. 1

At $\mathrm{pH}=10.0$

$[\mathrm{A}-]_{\text {total }}=\frac{K_{\mathrm{HA}} \times 0.06}{\left(K_{\mathrm{HA}}+1 \times 10^{-10}\right)}=0.06$

$\left[\mathrm{MA}^{+}\right]=K_{1}\left[\mathrm{M}^{2+}\right]\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]=2.1 \times 10^{3} \times 3.10 \times 10^{-4} \times\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]=0.651 \times\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]$

Eq. 3

$\left[\mathrm{MA}_{2}\right]=K_{1} K_{2}\left[\mathrm{M}^{2+}\right]\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]^{2}=325.5 \times\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]^{2}$

Eq. 4

$\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]_{\text {total }}=\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]+\left[\mathrm{MA}^{+}\right]+2 \times\left[\mathrm{MA}_{2}\right]=0.06$

Eq. 5

Substitution of the equations Eq. 3 and Eq. 4 into Eq. 5:

$\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]+0.651 \times\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]+2 \times 325.5 \times\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]^{2}=0.06$

Solution of this equation gives: $\left[A^{-}\right]=8.42 \times 10^{-3}$

After substitution of this value into Eq. 3 and Eq. 4:

$\left[\mathrm{MA}^{+}\right]=0.651 \times\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]=5.48 \times 10^{-3}$

$\left[\mathrm{MA}_{2}\right]=325.5 \times\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]^{2}=2.31 \times 10^{-2}$

Similarly,

$\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]_{\text {total }}=0.04$

$\left[\mathrm{MB}^{+}\right]=K_{1}{ }^{\prime}\left[\mathrm{M}^{2+}\right]\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]=6.2 \times 10^{-3} \times 3.10 \times 10^{-4} \times\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]=1.92 \times\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]$

Eq. 6

$\left[\mathrm{MB}_{2}\right]=K_{1}^{\prime} K_{2}^{\prime}\left[\mathrm{M}^{2+}\right]\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]^{2}=634.3 \times\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]^{2}$

Eq.. 7

$\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]_{\text {total }}=\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]+\left[\mathrm{MB}^{+}\right]+2 \times\left[\mathrm{MB}_{2}\right]=0.04$

Eq. 8

After substitution of Eq. 6 and Eq. 7 into Eq. 8:

$\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]+1.92 \times\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]+2 \times 634.3 \times\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]^{2}=0.04$

Solution of this equation: $\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]=4.58 \times 10^{-3}$

Substitution of this value into Eq. 6 and Eq. 7 :

$\left[\mathrm{MB}^{+}\right]=1.92 \times[\mathrm{B}]=8.79 \times 10^{-3}$

$\left[\mathrm{MB}_{2}\right]=634.3 \times\left[\mathrm{B}^{-}\right]^{2}=1.33 \times 10^{-2}$

Thus, solubility of $\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}$ in $\mathbf{Z}$ is $\mathbf{s}^{\prime}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{s}^{\prime}=3.10 \times 10^{-4}+5.48 \times 10^{-3}+2.31 \times 10^{-2}+ \\
&+8.79 \times 10^{-3}+1.33 \times 10^{-2}=5.10 \times 10^{-2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: Solubility of $\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}$ is $\mathrm{s}=5.10 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.

The hypochlorite concentration in bleach can be determined by treating it with excess iodide ion in acidic solution, which causes the formation of triiodide ion according to the following balanced reaction:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{OCl}^{-}(a q)+3 \mathrm{I}^{-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{O}^{+}(a q) \rightarrow \\
\mathrm{Cl}^{-}(a q)+\mathrm{I}_{3}^{-}(a q)+3 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l)
\end{gathered}
$$

The triiodide can then be titrated with sodium thiosulfate:

$$
\mathrm{I}_{3}^{-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow 3 \mathrm{I}^{-}(a q)+\mathrm{S}_{4} \mathrm{O}_{6}{ }^{2-}(a q)
$$

solution:
Enthalpy conservation condition: $-\mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B}+\mathbf{C}+\mathbf{D} / 2=\mathbf{F}-\mathbf{E}$

From the above equation: $-(-411)+109+496+(242 / 2)=F+349$

Thus: $F=788$

Lattice formation enthalpy of $\mathrm{NaCl}$ is $-\mathbf{F}$, thus $-788 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$.

problem:
In the 1980's a class of ceramic materials was discovered that exhibits superconductivity at the unusually high temperature of $90 \mathrm{~K}$. One such material contains yttrium, barium, copper and oxygen and is called "YBCO". It has a nominal composition of $\mathrm{YBa}_{2} \mathrm{Cu}_{3} \mathrm{O}_{7}$, but its actual composition is variable according to the formula $\mathrm{YBa}_{2} \mathrm{Cu}_{3} \mathrm{O}_{7-\delta}$ $(0<\delta<0.5)$.

Two identical samples of YBCO with an unknown value of $\delta$ were prepared. The first sample was dissolved in $5 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of aqueous $\mathrm{HCl}\left(c=1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)$, evolving $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. After boiling to expel gases, cooling, and addition of $10 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{KI}$ solution ( $c=0.7 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ ) under Ar, titration with thiosulfate to the starch endpoint required $1.542 \cdot 10^{-4}$ mol thiosulfate. The second sample of YBCO was added under Ar directly to $7 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of a solution in which $c(\mathrm{KI})=1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ and $\mathrm{c}(\mathrm{HCl})=0.7 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$. Titration of this solution required $1.696 \cdot 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mol}$ thiosulfate to reach the endpoint.Calculate the value of $\delta$ for these samples of YBCO.

You are participating in an international Chemistry competition and need to solve the following question.

Here is some context information for this question, which might assist you in solving it:
In the 1980's a class of ceramic materials was discovered that exhibits superconductivity at the unusually high temperature of $90 \mathrm{~K}$. One such material contains yttrium, barium, copper and oxygen and is called "YBCO". It has a nominal composition of $\mathrm{YBa}_{2} \mathrm{Cu}_{3} \mathrm{O}_{7}$, but its actual composition is variable according to the formula $\mathrm{YBa}_{2} \mathrm{Cu}_{3} \mathrm{O}_{7-\delta}$ $(0<\delta<0.5)$.

Two identical samples of YBCO with an unknown value of $\delta$ were prepared. The first sample was dissolved in $5 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of aqueous $\mathrm{HCl}\left(c=1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)$, evolving $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. After boiling to expel gases, cooling, and addition of $10 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{KI}$ solution ( $c=0.7 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ ) under Ar, titration with thiosulfate to the starch endpoint required $1.542 \cdot 10^{-4}$ mol thiosulfate. The second sample of YBCO was added under Ar directly to $7 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of a solution in which $c(\mathrm{KI})=1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ and $\mathrm{c}(\mathrm{HCl})=0.7 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$. Titration of this solution required $1.696 \cdot 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mol}$ thiosulfate to reach the endpoint.

problem:
Calculate the value of $\delta$ for these samples of YBCO.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value.
solution:
Total $n(\mathrm{Cu})=1.542 \cdot 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mol}$

$n\left(\mathrm{Cu}^{\mathrm{III}}\right)=\left(1.696 \cdot 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mol}\right)-\left(1.542 \cdot 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mol}\right)=1.54 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol}$

Thus: $90 \%$ of $\mathrm{Cu}$ is present as $\mathrm{Cu}(\mathrm{II})$ and $10 \%$ as $\mathrm{Cu}(\mathrm{III})$.

From charge balance:

$2(7-\delta)=3+(2 \times 2)+3 \times[(0.90 \times 2)+(0.10 \times 3)]=13.30$

$\delta=0.35$

Alternatively, using the balanced equations in (d):

In the $1^{\text {st }}$ titration, each mol $\mathrm{YBCO}$ corresponds $1.5 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{I}_{3}^{-}$and $3 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}$

In the $2^{\text {nd }}$ titration, each mol YBCO corresponds $(2-\delta) \mathrm{mol}_{3}^{-}$and $(4-2 \delta) \mathrm{mol} \mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}$

Thus,

$\frac{1.542 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mol}}{1.696 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mol}}=\frac{3}{4-2 \delta}=\frac{1.5}{2-\delta}$

$2-\delta=1.650$

$\delta=0.35$

##  electron configurations

We now know that elements in the same Group of the periodic table have similar properties because they have the same number of electrons in their outermost (valence) shell. In Mendeleev's second table, elements in the same Group have the same number of valence electrons, even though some elements are from the main block of the periodic table, and some from the transition metals.

Our modern periodic table is based on the electronic configurations of the elements.

For elements from Groups 1 and 2, the valence electrons are in $s$ orbitals whereas for elements in Groups 13-18, they are in $s$ and $p$ orbitals. In both cases the orbitals have principal quantum numbers the same as the period number.

For elements in Groups 3-12, the electrons are filling d orbitals in shells with principal quantum numbers one less that the period number. The valence electrons are the s electrons and perhaps some / all of the d electrons.

For the lanthanoids and actinoids, the electrons are filling $f$ orbitals in shells with principal quantum numbers two less than the period number.

 Give the full electron configurations of zinc in s, p, d notation.

problem: The unit cell is the smallest repeating unit in a crystal structure. The unit cell of a gold crystal is found by X-ray diffraction to have the face-centred cubic unit structure (i.e. where the centre of an atom is located at each corner of a cube and in the middle of each face). The side of the unit cell is found to be $0.408 \mathrm{~nm}$.The density of $\mathrm{Au}$ is $1.93 \cdot 10^{4} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Calculate the volume and mass of the cubic unit cell.
prompt:
You are participating in an international Chemistry competition and need to solve the following question.
The answer to this question is a numerical value.
Here is some context information for this question, which might assist you in solving it:
The unit cell is the smallest repeating unit in a crystal structure. The unit cell of a gold crystal is found by X-ray diffraction to have the face-centred cubic unit structure (i.e. where the centre of an atom is located at each corner of a cube and in the middle of each face). The side of the unit cell is found to be $0.408 \mathrm{~nm}$.

problem:
The density of $\mathrm{Au}$ is $1.93 \cdot 10^{4} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Calculate the volume and mass of the cubic unit cell.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of kg, but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.
solution:
Volume: $V=(0.408 \mathrm{~nm})^{3}=6.79 \cdot 10^{-29} \mathrm{~m}^{3}$

Mass: $m=\rho V=1.93 \cdot 10^{4} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3} \times 6.79 \cdot 10^{-29} \mathrm{~m}^{3}=1.31 \cdot 10^{-24} \mathrm{~kg}$

A titration volume of 17.50 $\mathrm{cm}^{3}$ was obtained for the back titration with $0.1050 \mathrm{M}$ sodium hydroxide.

Calculate the molecular weight of the amino acid based on one and two nitrogen groups in the molecule, respectively.

Schematically:

$2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+10 \mathrm{I}^{-}+16 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+5 \mathrm{I}_{2}+8 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ and

$\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{2-}+4 \mathrm{I}^{-}+8 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{I}_{2}+4 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2.5 n_{\mathrm{KMnO}_{4} \text { left }}+2 n_{\mathrm{K}_{2} \mathrm{MnO}_{4}}=2.5\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-10 n_{\mathrm{CA}}\right)+2 \times 10 n_{\mathrm{CA}} \\
& 2 \mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}+\mathrm{I}_{2}=\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{4} \mathrm{O}_{6}+2 \mathrm{Nal} \\
& n_{\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}}=2 n_{\mathrm{l}_{2}}=5\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-10 n_{\mathrm{CA}}\right)+40 n_{\mathrm{CA}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus:

$5\left(c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-10 n_{\mathrm{CA}}\right)+40 n_{\mathrm{CA}}=c_{\mathrm{S}} V_{\mathrm{S} 1}$,

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n_{\mathrm{CA}}=1 / 2 c_{\mathrm{Mn}} V_{\mathrm{Mn}}-0.1 c_{\mathrm{S}} V_{\mathrm{S} 1} \\
& n_{\mathrm{CA}}=(0.5 \times 0.0400 \times 10.00)-(0.1 \times 0.1000 \times 4.90)=0.151 \mathrm{mmol}, \\
& m_{\mathrm{CA}}=n_{\mathrm{CA}} M_{\mathrm{CA}}=13.00 \mathrm{mg} .
\end{aligned}
$$

problem:
Extraction of gold using sodium cyanide, a very poisonous chemical, causes environmental problems and gives rise to serious public concern about the use of this so called "cyanide process". Thiosulfate leaching of gold has been considered as an alternative. In this process, the main reagent is ammonium thiosulfate, $\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$, which is relatively non-toxic. Although this process appears to be environmentally benign, the chemistry involved is very complex and needs to be studied thoroughly. The solution used for leaching gold contains $\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}, \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}, \mathrm{NH}_{3}$, and dissolved $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. The solution must have a $\mathrm{pH}$ greater than 8.5 to allow free ammonia to be present.

According to the proposed mechanism, a local voltaic micro-cell is formed on the surface of gold particles during the leaching process and operates as follows:

Anode:

$\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{s})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+e^{-}$

$\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

Cathode:

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{4}\right]^{2+}(a q)+e^{-} \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+3 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{3}\right]^{5-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

The formation constants, $K_{f}$, of $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}$and $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}$ complexes are $1.00 \cdot 10^{26}$ and $1.00 \cdot 10^{28}$, respectively. Consider a leaching solution in which the equilibrium concentrations of the species are as follows:

$\left[\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2 \cdot}\right]=0.100 ;\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]=0.100$ and the total concentration of gold $(\mathrm{I})$ species $=$ $5.50 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.Calculate the percentage of gold $(I)$ ion that exists in the form of thiosulfate complex.

Anode:

$\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{s})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+e^{-}$

$\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

Cathode:

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{4}\right]^{2+}(a q)+e^{-} \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+3 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{3}\right]^{5-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

The formation constants, $K_{f}$, of $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}$and $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}$ complexes are $1.00 \cdot 10^{26}$ and $1.00 \cdot 10^{28}$, respectively. Consider a leaching solution in which the equilibrium concentrations of the species are as follows:

$\left[\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2 \cdot}\right]=0.100 ;\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]=0.100$ and the total concentration of gold $(\mathrm{I})$ species $=$ $5.50 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.

problem:
Calculate the percentage of gold $(I)$ ion that exists in the form of thiosulfate complex.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of %, but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.
solution:
$$
\begin{aligned} &
\mathrm{Au}^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq}) \quad \mathrm{K}_{f, 1}=1.00 \cdot 10^{26}  \\
& \mathrm{Au}^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}{ }^{2-}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(\mathrm{aq}) 
\quad \mathrm{K}_{f, 2}=1.00 \cdot 10^{28} 
\\
& {\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) } \\
& \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{K_{f, 2}}{\mathrm{~K}_{f, 1}}=1.00 \cdot 10^{2} \\
& {\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}+\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}=5.50 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}} \\
& \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{(0.100)^{2} x}{\left(5.50 \cdot 10^{-5}-x\right)(0.100)^{2}}=1.00 \cdot 10^{2} \\
& x=5.445 \cdot 10^{-5} \\
& \frac{5.445 \cdot 10^{-5}}{5.50 \cdot 10^{-5}} \times 100=99.0 \%
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $99.0 \%$ of $\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{I})$ is in the form of $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}$.

problem:
Contemporary means of transportation rely on burning fossil fuels, although the efficiency of real combustion engines is inherently limited and typically ranges between 20 and $40 \%$.

Fuel cells represent a way to improve the engine efficiency for future vehicles. The engine efficiency can be improved by using hydrogen-based fuel cells.Calculate the mass of hydrogen required to drive the distance between Prague and Bratislava $\left(330 \mathrm{~km}\right.$ ) at the average speed of $100 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}$ with a car fitted with a 310 $\mathrm{kW}$ electric engine running on average at a $15 \%$ rate of its maximum power. Assume that the efficiency of the hydrogen cell producing electrical energy is $75 \%$, the efficiency of the electric engine is $95 \%$, and the Gibbs energy change for combustion of hydrogen fuel is $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} G=-226 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$.

Contemporary means of transportation rely on burning fossil fuels, although the efficiency of real combustion engines is inherently limited and typically ranges between 20 and $40 \%$.

Fuel cells represent a way to improve the engine efficiency for future vehicles. The engine efficiency can be improved by using hydrogen-based fuel cells.

problem:
Calculate the mass of hydrogen required to drive the distance between Prague and Bratislava $\left(330 \mathrm{~km}\right.$ ) at the average speed of $100 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}$ with a car fitted with a 310 $\mathrm{kW}$ electric engine running on average at a $15 \%$ rate of its maximum power. Assume that the efficiency of the hydrogen cell producing electrical energy is $75 \%$, the efficiency of the electric engine is $95 \%$, and the Gibbs energy change for combustion of hydrogen fuel is $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} G=-226 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of kg, but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.
solution:
Driving time:

$$
T=\frac{S}{V}=\frac{330 \mathrm{~km}}{100 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1} / 3600 \mathrm{~s}}=11880 \mathrm{~s}
$$

determines the ideal amount of energy required to cover the given distance:

$$
W_{\text {ideal }}=P \times f \times T=310 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~W} \times 0.15 \times 11880 \mathrm{~s}=5.52 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~J}
$$

Assuming the overall non-unity efficiency, the real energy required is:

$$
W_{\text {real }}=\frac{W_{\text {ideal }}}{\eta_{\text {electrolysis }} \times \eta_{\text {engine }}}=\frac{5.52 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~J}}{0.75 \times 0.95}=7.75 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~J}
$$

This can be combined with the standard Gibbs energy of liquid water formation to yield the amount of hydrogen:

$$
m=\frac{W_{\text {real }}}{\left|\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} G^{\circ}\right|} \times M=\frac{7.75 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~J}}{2.26 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}} \times 2.02 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}=6.93 \mathrm{~kg}
$$

##  electron configurations

We now know that elements in the same Group of the periodic table have similar properties because they have the same number of electrons in their outermost (valence) shell. In Mendeleev's second table, elements in the same Group have the same number of valence electrons, even though some elements are from the main block of the periodic table, and some from the transition metals.

Our modern periodic table is based on the electronic configurations of the elements.

For elements from Groups 1 and 2, the valence electrons are in $s$ orbitals whereas for elements in Groups 13-18, they are in $s$ and $p$ orbitals. In both cases the orbitals have principal quantum numbers the same as the period number.

For elements in Groups 3-12, the electrons are filling d orbitals in shells with principal quantum numbers one less that the period number. The valence electrons are the s electrons and perhaps some / all of the d electrons.

For the lanthanoids and actinoids, the electrons are filling $f$ orbitals in shells with principal quantum numbers two less than the period number.

Given the maximum oxidation states of elements in Groups 2 and 12 are +2, what are the valence electrons of mercury?

problem:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Adding large amounts of distilled water to solution $\mathbf{X}$ gives a very (infinitely) dilute solution where the total concentrations of the acids are close to zero. Calculate the percentage of dissociation of each acid in this dilute solution.
prompt:
You are participating in an international Chemistry competition and need to solve the following question.
This question involves multiple quantities to be determined.
Here is some context information for this question, which might assist you in solving it:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.

problem:
Adding large amounts of distilled water to solution $\mathbf{X}$ gives a very (infinitely) dilute solution where the total concentrations of the acids are close to zero. Calculate the percentage of dissociation of each acid in this dilute solution.

All mathematical formulas and symbols you output should be represented with LaTeX!
You can solve it step by step.
Your final quantities should be output in the following order: [the percentage of dissociation of HA, the percentage of dissociation of HB].
Their units are, in order, [%, %], but units shouldn't be included in your concluded answer.
Their answer types are, in order, [numerical value, numerical value].
Please end your response with: "The final answers are \boxed{ANSWER}", where ANSWER should be the sequence of your final answers, separated by commas, for example: 5, 7, 2.5
solution:
Solution: HA in the dilute solution:

$\left[\mathrm{A}^{-}\right]=\alpha \times[\mathrm{HA}]_{\mathrm{i}}$

$[\mathrm{HA}]=(1-\alpha) \times[\mathrm{HA}]_{\mathrm{i}}$

$\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]=10^{-7}$

Substitution of the above equilibrium concentrations into $K_{H A}$ expression:

$\frac{10^{-7} \alpha[\mathrm{HA}]_{\mathrm{i}}}{(1-\alpha)[\mathrm{HA}]_{\mathrm{i}}}=K_{\mathrm{HA}} \quad$ or $\frac{10^{-7} \alpha}{(1-\alpha)}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$

The solving of the equation gives: $\alpha=0.635$

Similarly, for HB:

$$
\frac{10^{-7} \alpha}{(1-\alpha)}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}
$$

The solving of the equation gives: $\alpha=0.573$

- The percentage of dissociation of $\mathrm{HA}=\mathbf{6 5 . 5 \%}$
- The percentage of dissociation of $\mathrm{HB}=\mathbf{5 7 . 3} \%$
answer_sequence: the percentage of dissociation of HA
the percentage of dissociation of HB

solution:
The rate of production of energy (power) in watts ( $1 \mathrm{~W}=\mathrm{J} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$ ) produced by 1.00 kilogram of ${ }^{232} \mathrm{Th}\left(t_{\mathrm{t} / 2}=1.40 \times 10^{10}\right.$ years).

$1.00 \mathrm{~kg}$ contains $=\frac{1000 \mathrm{~g} \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}}{232 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}}=2.60 \times 10^{24}$ atoms

Decay constant for ${ }^{232} \mathrm{Th}$ :

$$
\lambda=\frac{0.693}{1.40 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{y} \times 3.154 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{sy}^{-1}}=1.57 \times 10^{-18} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}
$$

For activity: $A=N \quad \lambda=2.60 \times 10^{24} \times 1.57 \times 10^{-18}=4.08 \times 10^{6}$ dis s $^{-1}$

(disintegrations $\mathrm{S}^{-1}$ )

Each decay liberates $42.67 \mathrm{MeV}$

Rate of production of energy (power):

$4.08 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{dis} \mathrm{s}^{-1} \times 42.67 \mathrm{MeV} \mathrm{dis}^{-1} \times 1.602 \times 10^{-13} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{MeV}^{-1}=$

$=2.79 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}=2.79 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~W}$

problem:
This question is about the chlorides of a mythical metal

The mythical metal stuck-at-homium, symbol Sk, forms just two chlorides $-\mathrm{SkCl}_{2}$ which is a white solid, and $\mathrm{SkCl}_{4}$, a colourless volatile oily liquid which fumes on contact with air. The preparation of $\mathrm{SkCl}_{4}$ was first described over four hundred years ago, but its formation may well have been described earlier and may have been one of the winged dragons referred to by the alchemists.

Aqueous $\mathrm{SkCl}_{2}$ is easily prepared by dissolving metallic stuck-at-homium in dilute hydrochloric acid. On evaporation, the dihydrate is produced, $\mathrm{SkCl}_{2} \cdot 2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$. This can be dehydrated to give anhydrous $\mathrm{SkCl}_{2}$ using ethanoic anhydride, $\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{CO}\right)_{2} \mathrm{O}$. The structure of solid anhydrous $\mathrm{SkCl}_{2}$ consists of chains of $\mathrm{SkCl}_{2}$ units in which there are two different $\mathrm{Sk}-\mathrm{Cl}$ bond lengths and two different chlorine environments. The anhydrous solid melts and then boils at a temperature less than $700^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

To prepare $\mathrm{SkCl}_{4}$ from $\mathrm{SkCl}_{2}$, an oxidising agent must be used. One preparation uses $\mathrm{HgCl}_{2}$. Mercury forms two chlorides: $\mathrm{HgCl}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{Hg}_{2} \mathrm{Cl}_{2}$.

Give TWO different equations for the preparation of $\mathrm{SkCl}_{4}$ from $\mathrm{SkCl}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{HgCl}_{2}$.

Since the structure of the atom was completely unknown at the time, there was no concept of atomic number and the elements were ordered by their atomic masses. The numbers shown in the table are the atomic masses as known at the time. ## the misplacement of thallium

Mendeleev also misplaced the highly toxic element thallium ( $\mathrm{Tl}$ ) with the elements from Group 1 rather than in Group 13. There are good reasons for this error. Thallium can form salts in the +3 oxidation state like other members of its group, but $\mathrm{Tl}^{3+}$ ions are oxidising and the most stable oxidation state is +1 . For example, adding iodide ions to solutions of $\mathrm{Tl}^{3+}$ actually gives a precipitate of thallium $(\mathrm{I})$ iodide.

An iodide of thallium with the formula $\mathrm{THI}_{3}$ is known and has exactly the same structure as $\mathrm{CsI}_{3}$.

What is the average oxidation state of the iodine in these compounds?

problem:
For sustainable energy, hydrogen appears to be the best energy carrier. The most efficient way of using hydrogen is generation of electrical energy in a fuel cell. However, storing hydrogen in large quantities is a challenge in fuel cell applications. Among the chemical hydrides considered as solid hydrogen storage materials, sodium borohydride $\left(\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}\right)$, being non-toxic, stable and environmentally benign, appears to be the most promising one. The hydrolysis of sodium borohydride that releases $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ gas is a slow reaction at ambient temperature and, therefore, needs to be catalyzed.

$$
\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(I)  \xrightarrow{catalyst} \mathrm{Na}^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{BO}_{2}^{-}(\mathrm{aq})+4 \mathrm{H}_{2}(g)
$$

Colloidal ruthenium(0) nanoclusters are the most active catalysts in this hydrolysis even at room temperature and lead to a complete $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ release from sodium borohydride. Kinetic studies show that the catalytic hydrolysis of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ is a first order reaction with respect to the catalyst, but a zero order with respect to the substrate. The rate of hydrogen production per mole of ruthenium is $92 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_{2} \cdot(\mathrm{mol} \mathrm{Ru})^{-1} \cdot \min ^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.Calculate the volume of air at a temperature of $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and a pressure of $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$ needed to generate a constant current of $2.5 \mathrm{~A}$ for 3.0 hours in this fuel cell. Assume that air contains $20 \%$ by volume $\mathrm{O}_{2}(\mathrm{g})$.

problem:
Calculation of ZPE and KIE

Kinetic isotope effect (KIE) is a phenomenon associated with a change in rate constant of the reaction when one of the atoms is replaced by its isotope. KIE can be used to confirm whether a particular bond to hydrogen is broken in the reaction. Harmonic oscillator model is used to estimate the difference in the rate between $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{H}$ and ${ }^{1} \mathrm{C}-\mathrm{D}$ bond activation ( $\mathrm{D}-$ deuterium).

The vibrational frequency $(v)$ represented by harmonic oscillator model is

$$
v=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{k}{\mu}}
$$

where $k$ is the force constant and $\mu$ is the reduced mass.

The vibrational energies of the molecule are given by

$$
E_{n}=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) h v
$$

where $n$ is vibrational quantum number with possible values of $0,1,2, \ldots$ The energy of the lowest vibrational energy level ( $\mathrm{E}_{n}$ at $n=0$ ) is called zero-point vibrational energy (ZPE).Calculate the reduced mass of $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{D}\left(\mu_{\mathrm{CD}}\right)$ in atomic mass unit. Assume that the mass of deuterium is twice that of hydrogen.

Note: If a student is unable to calculate the values for $\mu_{\text { }}$ and $\mu_{\mathrm{CD}}$ he/she can use $\mu_{C H}=1.008$ and $\mu_{C D}=2.016$ for the subsequent parts of the question. The given values are not necessarily be close to the correct values.

Calculation of ZPE and KIE

Kinetic isotope effect (KIE) is a phenomenon associated with a change in rate constant of the reaction when one of the atoms is replaced by its isotope. KIE can be used to confirm whether a particular bond to hydrogen is broken in the reaction. Harmonic oscillator model is used to estimate the difference in the rate between $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{H}$ and ${ }^{1} \mathrm{C}-\mathrm{D}$ bond activation ( $\mathrm{D}-$ deuterium).

The vibrational frequency $(v)$ represented by harmonic oscillator model is

$$
v=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{k}{\mu}}
$$

where $k$ is the force constant and $\mu$ is the reduced mass.

The vibrational energies of the molecule are given by

$$
E_{n}=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) h v
$$

where $n$ is vibrational quantum number with possible values of $0,1,2, \ldots$ The energy of the lowest vibrational energy level ( $\mathrm{E}_{n}$ at $n=0$ ) is called zero-point vibrational energy (ZPE).

problem:
Calculate the reduced mass of $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{D}\left(\mu_{\mathrm{CD}}\right)$ in atomic mass unit. Assume that the mass of deuterium is twice that of hydrogen.

Note: If a student is unable to calculate the values for $\mu_{\text { }}$ and $\mu_{\mathrm{CD}}$ he/she can use $\mu_{C H}=1.008$ and $\mu_{C D}=2.016$ for the subsequent parts of the question. The given values are not necessarily be close to the correct values.

Remember, your answer should be calculated in the unit of amu, but when concluding your final answer, do not include the unit.
Please end your response with: "The final answer is $\boxed{ANSWER}$", where ANSWER is the numerical value without any units.

solution:
$\Delta H_{\text {rxn }}=-\left\{H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{C})+H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})+6 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{H})+H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{H})\right\}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& +\left\{2 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})+8 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{H})\right\} \\
= & -\left\{1.77 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})+H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})+6\left(1.19 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})+1.05\left(1.19 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})\right\}\right.\right. \\
+ & \left\{2 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})+8\left(1.19 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})\right\}=+0.360 H_{\text {bond }}(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{C})\right.
\end{aligned}
$$
